Vote if you think the Iron Golems should be improved

The Iron golem is not looking for dangers to you, it is looking for dangers to the villagers, and protecting you is a bi-product. this is why it hangs around villages, and does not attack creepers, which are of no harm to villagers. Skeletons are undead, somewhat resembling zombies, and spiders scare the villagers, which is why the golem goes after them. It is a robot and takes a moment to assess the threat. It is intentional.
I also think that Endermen in the end should attack you when you strike the Ender Dragon as I assume that the dragon is their king

I think it is a pretty good idea. Maybe add more details of why it would be really cool to be added into the game. Also, if you want people to vote for you more, make sure they feel that it would be an amazing thing to add into the game. Correct grammar and spelling would also be a plus. Overall, I like this idea, thus I voted for it. Peace. Stay cool.

I know that its something similar but isnt the same, because this mob drop a book that, if you build a tower with nether  blocks and drop the book in the top, the book give you fire superpowers Like throw fireballs . Isnt a totem like a simple item, its a power building.
This is not a lumberjack, this is a carpenter or joiner.
What block will determine the job? A new block or an old one?
Mabey a new block? Wood bench! It wil be made with 6 planks(any type) or logs in the bottom of the grid, and 3 copper on top.
I agree. They have a big problem with stairs, not to mention ladders.

1.20.1, they lose track of their workstations, get their beds mixed-up, sometimes leading to a surprise infinite breeder scenario, but don't worry!  You can kill them all with a bed behind a lava hole with an open trapdoor over it.  As previously mentioned, multi-floor buildings are a no-go.  Their AI is almost as broken as one of their savanna villages.

And during a raid, they're furiously bouncing around inside their little houses, like they're just trying to see who can get killed by the ravager first.

By the marketing, Microsoft allegedly has all of this AI prowess, but getting the squidwards to find their beds is more than MSFT's wizards can handle.

I am so heard of this. Recently improved a plains village then it quickly become a mess when villagers selects the shortest path possible even if it is blocked by a block.

 

Improving and populating a village is pointless when those villagers does not learn how to get to either workstations or beds or even go to a second floor.

Librarians will use a spell book to cast spells on allies for example the iron golem gets a hp and strength boost or villagers get a shield around them that reduces damage and heals them

Enemies well librarians can place spells such as weakness,blindness and slowness but not to harm enemies but to slow them and make it easier for you to deal with 

Shepherds will shear sheep,milk cows and breed and raise animals.
this makes sense. it would add some interesting game play

While an annoying difference, all this does is make it take you a couple more minutes to set up the farm (unless you donâ€™t have enough villagers, but itâ€™s still not that bad). I donâ€™t think this is that serious. How many iron farms do you need?

It's more or less just a pain, I feel like they should be a little easier. Java Iron farms are a little simpler. And it would make it a lot easier. I don't like going mining for iron. So I always have one iron farm. And it is a bit annoying to set one up in bedrock. It would be great if it would be the same as java. And the amount of people who try to set up an iron farm on bedrock, I would say 25-50% don't know how to make one or it just won't work. That's all, I would just love to see Minecraft java and bedrock farms the same.

They are amazing if you don't want to run around getting iron, and for big projects that might require a massive amount of iron, it is a life saver. It is op. But it is annoying to set up... I hate villagers they are super irritating, especially in bedrock.

And itâ€™s not just the Iron farm. There are a lot of fun and necessary to build farms in Java edition and they do not work in bedrock. For example a wood farm. I donâ€™t understand why a game has 2 different versions, it does not make any sense. Why Java players can make a hole in nether roof but bedrock players canâ€™t? Why are the rates of an enderman farm in Java is significantly higher than in bedrock? The farms are built literally similarly. Donâ€™t let me start on how many different options you have for like a gold farm or a creeper farm in java, while there is only one function farm for each of them in bedrock and the rates are incomparable.
This is just not fair.

But if a zombie "kill" an illager, this one would become a zombie villager that become a normal villager if cured ( like if he were grateful and forgot his evilness). Anyway, as illagers are armed, it would be hard and unusual for zombies to kill illagers.

It messes with the lore a bit, because Illagers arenâ€™t like zombies. They were born that way, so it wouldnâ€™t make sense. For ravagers and maybe vindicators, different story. Ravagers arenâ€™t technically Illagers and a theory is that they were villagers turned into ravagers. Itâ€™s the same for vindicators.

I really think this would add more personality to mobs. But, then Halloween wouldn't exactly be scary: it's the one day where you can just not worry about mobs. I'd suggest that they'd attack you still, but still while dancing, just to get the vibes.

I like this, but how would it work? Also, you can kinda already do this in creative mode using spawn eggs.

I like the idea of good or evil alignment. There's a few things that I think would need to be worked out for sure:

1. Regular villages don't have anything for defense but Iron Golems. Yet Pillagers have Vindicators and Ravagers as support. Maybe villages would need their own "Soldiers" or armed security?

2. Neither side has anything that's very valuable usually. So a "Raid" would be sort of useless for the player. Most of the time it's just misc. items in chests for outposts and villages. Plus doesn't an "outpost" suggest a much larger group is out there somewhere? Food for thought. 

3. If Pillagers are hostile by default, how do you get on their good side? Travel to an outpost and offer some sort of goods as appeasement? Or do you just need to craft an ominous banner and carry it to their outpost? Again, food for thought.

4. If there's good or evil alignment, does that mean that a player starts Neutral? Or is a player good until proven Evil? 

5. If there's Good and Evil wouldn't that potentially mean ongoing wars? Or does it mean that until a player picks a side both sides are at a stalemate?
This should totally be a thing. If you discover a pillager about to kill someone and then kill the pillager you should get especially good trades from that villager.

Es verdad

i like it maybe you vould by the town for like 100 emlread s or something and when you trade with him he would give the stuff for free
this is a great idea

Yea, Wandering traders are annoying, especially on melon/pumpkin farms. Had a lot of times where the wandering trader and its llamas would spawn well within the confines of my melon and pumpkin farms.

They can trample on the farmland since the melons and pumpkins make the ground uneven, necessitating jumps to the fruits then sometimes to the farmland. When that happens, I would have to plow and regrow the melon and pumpkin plants, frankly annoying to say the least. I would have to kill them to prevent further damage to the farm.

If there would be a trading post or some marker that defines wandering trader AND/OR a no-spawn zone defining block for the traders, I would stop killing them.
I really like this idea, it reminds me of the Fallout 4 caravan post, which made Fallout settlements feel more alive with visitors.
Hey there I am sure there are a lot of useless items but has high price that you would wanted to exchange with more useful items such as netherite hoe or prismerines.
